# Overtime (ice hockey)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This article **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. **Overtime** is a method of determining a winner in an [ice
hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey") game when the score is tied after
regulation. The main methods of determining a winner in a tied game are the
overtime period (commonly referred to as **overtime**), the
[shootout](/wiki/Penalty_shootout "Penalty shootout"), or a combination of
both. If league rules dictate a finite time in which overtime may be played,
with no penalty shoot-out to follow, the game's winning team may or may not be
necessarily determined.

## Overtime
periods[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Overtime periods")]

**Overtime periods** are extra [periods](/wiki/Ice_hockey#Periods_and_overtime
"Ice hockey") beyond the third regulation period during a game, where normal
hockey rules apply. Although in the past, full-length overtime periods were
played, overtimes today are _[golden goal](/wiki/Golden_goal "Golden goal")_
(a form of _[sudden death](/wiki/Sudden_death_\(sport\) "Sudden death
\(sport\)")_), meaning that the game ends immediately when a player scores a
[goal](/wiki/Goal_\(ice_hockey\) "Goal \(ice hockey\)").

### North American
overtime[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: North American overtime")]

From November 21, 1942,[1] when overtime was eliminated due to war time
restrictions and continuing until the
[1983–84](/wiki/1983%E2%80%9384_NHL_season "1983–84 NHL season") season, all
[NHL](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League") regular-season
games tied after 60 minutes of play ended as ties. On June 23, 1983, the NHL
introduced a regular-season overtime period of five minutes. If the five-
minute overtime period ended with no scoring, the game ended as a tie (the
World Hockey Association had used a 10-minute regular season overtime period,
as had the NHL prior to World War II). In the first games to go to overtime,
on October 5, 1983, the Minnesota North Stars and Los Angeles Kings skated to
a 3–3 tie, and the Detroit Red Wings and Winnipeg Jets tied 6–6. The first
regular-season game decided by overtime was on October 8, 1983, as the New
York Islanders beat the Washington Capitals 8–7.[2]

In [1987–88](/wiki/1987%E2%80%9388_AHL_season "1987–88 AHL season") and since
[1995](/wiki/1995%E2%80%9396_AHL_season "1995–96 AHL season"), the [American
Hockey League](/wiki/American_Hockey_League "American Hockey League") has
awarded teams one point in the standings for an overtime loss (OTL). In 1998,
the AHL introduced a rule where teams will play the five-minute overtime
period with four skaters and a goaltender, rather than at full strength (five
skaters), except in two-man advantage situations. In a two-man advantage
situation, the team with the advantage will play with five skaters against
three skaters. The rule was popular and adopted by the NHL and
[ECHL](/wiki/ECHL "ECHL") the next season.

[Alex Ovechkin](/wiki/Alexander_Ovechkin "Alexander Ovechkin") has the record
for most NHL overtime goals with 20.

In the [Stanley Cup playoffs](/wiki/Stanley_Cup_playoffs "Stanley Cup
playoffs") and in all [one-game playoffs](/wiki/One-game_playoff "One-game
playoff"), overtime periods are played like regulation periods except for the
[golden goal](/wiki/Golden_goal "Golden goal") rule – in an overtime period,
the game ends when one team scores a goal; the teams are at full strength
(five skaters, barring penalties), there is no shootout, and each overtime
period is 20 minutes with full intermissions between overtime periods. Three
of the game's legendary players, [Mark Messier](/wiki/Mark_Messier "Mark
Messier") (109 playoff goals), [Mario Lemieux](/wiki/Mario_Lemieux "Mario
Lemieux") (77 goals), and [Gordie Howe](/wiki/Gordie_Howe "Gordie Howe") (68
goals) never scored a playoff overtime goal.

In many leagues (including the NHL for regular-season games since the [2005–06
season](/wiki/2005%E2%80%9306_NHL_season "2005–06 NHL season")) and in
international competitions, a failure to reach a decision in a single overtime
may lead to a shootout. Some leagues may eschew overtime periods altogether
and end games in shootout should teams be tied at the end of regulation. In
the [ECHL](/wiki/ECHL "ECHL"), regular season overtime periods are played four
on four for one five-minute period. In the [Southern Professional Hockey
League](/wiki/Southern_Professional_Hockey_League "Southern Professional
Hockey League"), regular season overtime periods are played three on three for
one five-minute period, with penalties resulting in the opponents skating one
additional player on ice (up to two additional players) for the penalty for
the first three minutes, and a penalty shot in the final two minutes. The AHL,
since the [2014–15 season](/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_AHL_season "2014–15 AHL
season"), extended the overtime to seven minutes, with the last three minutes
reduced further to three men aside and teams getting an additional skater for
each opponent's penalty.[3] The idea of using 3-on-3 skaters for the entirety
of a five-minute overtime period for a regular season game was adopted by the
NHL on June 24, 2015, for use in the [2015–16 NHL
season](/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_NHL_season "2015–16 NHL season").[4]

### International
overtime[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: International overtime")]

In IIHF play, rules for overtime depend on the stage of the competition. For a
round robin or preliminary round game that goes to overtime, the teams will
play a maximum of five minutes of 3-on-3 hockey in the "golden goal" format.
If no one scores in the five minute overtime, a three-round shootout will
decide the winner. In the case of a playoff game or a bronze medal game, the
teams will play a maximum of ten minutes of 4-on-4 hockey in the "golden goal"
format. If there is no score in the overtime, a five-round shootout will
decide the winner. If the gold medal game of a top category IIHF championship
goes to overtime, the teams will play a maximum of twenty minutes of 5-on-5
hockey in the "golden goal" format. If there is no winner after the overtime,
a five-round shootout will decide the winner. In all cases, the teams must
change ends, and defend the same side that they did in the second period.[5]

##
Shootout[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Shootout")]

### International
shootouts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: International shootouts")]

In international competition, **shootouts** (or more formally, **game-winning
shots (GWS)** , and, in some European countries, **bullets,** or
**bullits**[6][7]), are often used. Each coach selects three skaters from
their team to take [penalty shots](/wiki/Penalty_shot_\(ice_hockey\) "Penalty
shot \(ice hockey\)") one at a time against the opposing
[goaltender](/wiki/Goaltender "Goaltender"), with teams alternating shots.
Each team gets one shot per round. The winner is the team with more goals
after three rounds or the team that amasses an unreachable advantage before
then (ex. a team gains a two-goal lead with only one round left). If the
shootout is tied after three rounds, tie-breaker rounds are played one at a
time (with each team taking one additional shot) until there is a winner.

The IIHF first adopted the game-winning-shot procedure in 1992 when a new
playoff procedure in the Winter Olympics and World Championships required a
winner for each game. At that time, the shootout was five rounds and only used
for knock-out games. In 2006, it was reduced to three rounds and used for all
games, eliminating the possibility of tied games at IIHF events. Tie-breaker
rounds are still used as needed, and the same or new players can take the tie-
break shots, which is also done in reverse order.[8] As of May 2016, all IIHF
preliminary round games that are not decided by overtime, are decided by a
three-round shootout. However, all playoff, bronze medal games and gold medal
games of IIHF top level championships (especially the Olympics) are decided by
five round shootouts.[5]

### North American
shootouts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: North American shootouts")]

Most lower minor leagues (ECHL, Central, [UHL](/wiki/United_Hockey_League
"United Hockey League")) have featured a shootout where, at the end of
regulation, a shootout similar to the international tournament format is used.

However, in 2000, the ECHL adopted the AHL's four-on-four overtime before the
shootout.

For the [2004–05 AHL season](/wiki/2004%E2%80%9305_AHL_season "2004–05 AHL
season"), the AHL adopted a five-man shootout, which was first used in that
league in 1986–87. The standard five-man shootout is used after four-on-four
overtime for all minor leagues in North America. The AHL switched to the NHL
formatted three-man shootout for the 2014–15 season.[3]

The Central Collegiate Hockey Association added the shootout as of the 2008–09
season.

Following the lead of minor leagues, as of the [2005–06
season](/wiki/2005%E2%80%9306_NHL_season "2005–06 NHL season"), the NHL ends
exhibition and regular season games still tied after a five-minute-length,
three-skaters-per-side overtime period (as of the [2015–16 NHL
season](/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_NHL_season "2015–16 NHL season") onwards) with a
shootout. The NHL format is a three-round shootout with tiebreaker rounds as
needed. All skaters (except goalies) on a team's roster must shoot before any
player can shoot a second time. On December 16, 2014 the longest shootout in
NHL history went to 20 rounds before [Nick Bjugstad](/wiki/Nick_Bjugstad "Nick
Bjugstad") of the [Florida Panthers](/wiki/Florida_Panthers "Florida
Panthers") scored to defeat the [Washington
Capitals](/wiki/Washington_Capitals "Washington Capitals"); the previous
record was 15 rounds.[9]

The shootout is not used in the playoffs for any North American league.
Instead, full 20-minute overtime periods are played until [one team scores a
goal](/wiki/Golden_goal "Golden goal").

In the [National Hockey League](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey
League") and [American Hockey League](/wiki/American_Hockey_League "American
Hockey League") All-Star Skills Competitions, the competition ends in a
penalty shootout known as the _Breakaway Relay_.

###
Tactics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Tactics")]

Tactics are very important during penalty shots and overtime shootouts for
both the shooter and the goalie. Both shooters and goalies commonly consult
their teammates and coaches for advice on the opposing player's style of play.
Shooters often consider the goalie's strengths and weaknesses (such as a fast
glove or stick [save](/wiki/Save_\(ice_hockey\) "Save \(ice hockey\)")),
preferred goaltending style (such as [butterfly](/wiki/Butterfly_style
"Butterfly style") or [stand-up](/wiki/Stand-up_style "Stand-up style")) and
method of challenging the shooter. Goaltenders often consider the shooter's
shot preference, expected angle of attack, a patented move a shooter commonly
uses and even handedness of the shooter.

Most shooters attempt to [out-deke](/wiki/Deke_\(ice_hockey\) "Deke \(ice
hockey\)") the goalie in order to create a better scoring chance. Former
[Detroit Red Wings](/wiki/Detroit_Red_Wings "Detroit Red Wings") forward
[Pavel Datsyuk](/wiki/Pavel_Datsyuk "Pavel Datsyuk") and [New York
Rangers](/wiki/New_York_Rangers "New York Rangers") forward [Martin St.
Louis](/wiki/Martin_St._Louis "Martin St. Louis") are examples of players who
commonly use this tactic. However, it is not uncommon for a shooter to simply
shoot for an opening without deking. This is commonly referred to as
[sniping](/wiki/List_of_ice_hockey_terminology "List of ice hockey
terminology"). This is most commonly performed when a goalie challenges a
shooter by giving them an open hole (by keeping a glove, pad or stick out of
position or being out of sound goaltending position altogether to tempt the
shooter to aim for the given opening). Former NHL forwards [Markus
Näslund](/wiki/Markus_N%C3%A4slund "Markus Näslund") and [Brett
Hull](/wiki/Brett_Hull "Brett Hull") are two players commonly referred to as
[snipers](/wiki/List_of_ice_hockey_terminology "List of ice hockey
terminology"). Very rarely a shooter may take a [slapshot](/wiki/Slapshot
"Slapshot") or [wrist shot](/wiki/Wrist_shot "Wrist shot") from the
[point](/wiki/Point_\(ice_hockey\) "Point \(ice hockey\)") or top of the
[slot](/wiki/Slot_\(ice_hockey\) "Slot \(ice hockey\)"). This is almost
exclusively performed when a shooter either has a high level of confidence in
their shot or they attempt to catch the goalie by surprise. Retired player
[Brian Rolston](/wiki/Brian_Rolston "Brian Rolston"), [Detroit Red
Wings](/wiki/Detroit_Red_Wings "Detroit Red Wings") winger [Todd
Bertuzzi](/wiki/Todd_Bertuzzi "Todd Bertuzzi"), [Philadelphia
Flyers](/wiki/Philadelphia_Flyers "Philadelphia Flyers") defenseman [Chris
Pronger](/wiki/Chris_Pronger "Chris Pronger"), and [Vancouver
Canucks](/wiki/Vancouver_Canucks "Vancouver Canucks") winger [Daniel
Sedin](/wiki/Daniel_Sedin "Daniel Sedin") have all used this tactic with
success.

## List of notable overtime
games[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: List of notable overtime games")]

The [longest overtime game](/wiki/Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)#Norwegian_hockey
"Overtime \(ice hockey\)") in history was an in Norwegian [GET-
ligaen](/wiki/GET-ligaen "GET-ligaen"). The game ended after 157:14 of
overtime, in the 8th overtime period.

#### Notable NHL playoff overtime
games[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Notable NHL playoff overtime games")]

  * March 24, 1936: The [Detroit Red Wings](/wiki/Detroit_Red_Wings "Detroit Red Wings")' [Mud Bruneteau](/wiki/Mud_Bruneteau "Mud Bruneteau") ends the longest Stanley Cup playoff game to date, scoring the game's only goal in a 1–0 victory over the [Montreal Maroons](/wiki/Montreal_Maroons "Montreal Maroons"). The goal comes at 16:30 of sextuple overtime for a total of 176:30 of game play. It is also the longest NHL ice hockey game ever played. The game is a mere 3:30 short of the equivalent of playing three games back-to-back-to-back.
  * February 4, 1939: The [Boston Bruins](/wiki/Boston_Bruins "Boston Bruins")' [Mel Hill](/wiki/Mel_Hill "Mel Hill") scores his third overtime goal of the Bruins' Stanley Cup semi-final series against the [New York Rangers](/wiki/New_York_Rangers "New York Rangers"), setting an unsurpassed (as of now) NHL record for most overtime goals in a single playoff series, earning him the nickname thereafter of "Sudden Death" Hill. The series itself involves four overtime games, two of which go to triple overtime.
  * April 23, 1950: [Pete Babando](/wiki/Pete_Babando "Pete Babando") scores at 8:31 of double overtime to give the Detroit Red Wings a 4–3 win in the seventh game of the [1950 Stanley Cup Finals](/wiki/1950_Stanley_Cup_Finals "1950 Stanley Cup Finals") over the New York Rangers. It is the first time that a seventh game of a Final series goes to overtime.
  * April 21, 1951: [Bill Barilko](/wiki/Bill_Barilko "Bill Barilko") scores at 2:53 of overtime to give the [Toronto Maple Leafs](/wiki/Toronto_Maple_Leafs "Toronto Maple Leafs") a 3–2 win in the fifth game of the [1951 Stanley Cup Finals](/wiki/1951_Stanley_Cup_Finals "1951 Stanley Cup Finals") over the [Montreal Canadiens](/wiki/Montreal_Canadiens "Montreal Canadiens"). All five games in the series need to have overtime to be decided.
  * April 16, 1954: [Tony Leswick](/wiki/Tony_Leswick "Tony Leswick")'s shot hit Montreal Canadiens' defenceman [Doug Harvey](/wiki/Doug_Harvey_\(ice_hockey\) "Doug Harvey \(ice hockey\)")'s glove and went into the net at 4:20 of overtime to give the Detroit Red Wings a 2–1 win in the seventh game of the [1954 Stanley Cup Finals](/wiki/1954_Stanley_Cup_Finals "1954 Stanley Cup Finals") over the Canadiens. No seventh game of a Final series has gone to overtime since.
  * April 23, 1964: [Bobby Baun](/wiki/Bobby_Baun "Bobby Baun") of the [Toronto Maple Leafs](/wiki/Toronto_Maple_Leafs "Toronto Maple Leafs") nets a game winner against Detroit 1:43 into overtime in game six of the Finals to tie the series 3–all. The goal is notable because Baun broke his ankle earlier in the game. It was frozen and taped, and Baun returned to the ice to score the winning goal.
  * May 10, 1970: One of the most indelible moments in sports history is the sight of [Bobby Orr](/wiki/Bobby_Orr "Bobby Orr")'s "in flight" goal that gave the Boston Bruins a 4–3 win and a four-game sweep of the [St. Louis Blues](/wiki/St._Louis_Blues "St. Louis Blues") in the Stanley Cup Finals.
  * May 24, 1980: [Bob Nystrom](/wiki/Bob_Nystrom "Bob Nystrom") of the [New York Islanders](/wiki/New_York_Islanders "New York Islanders") scores the Stanley Cup clinching goal at 7:11 of overtime, beating the Philadelphia Flyers in six games for the title.
  * April 14, 1981: After sitting on the bench for the entire game, [Mike Crombeen](/wiki/Mike_Crombeen "Mike Crombeen") scored the winning goal at 5:16 of double overtime to give the [St. Louis Blues](/wiki/St._Louis_Blues "St. Louis Blues") a 4-3 win over the [Pittsburgh Penguins](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins "Pittsburgh Penguins").
  * April 10, 1982: "[Miracle on Manchester](/wiki/Miracle_on_Manchester "Miracle on Manchester")" – Rookie [Daryl Evans](/wiki/Daryl_Evans "Daryl Evans") gives the [Los Angeles Kings](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Kings "Los Angeles Kings") a 6–5 win over the [Edmonton Oilers](/wiki/Edmonton_Oilers "Edmonton Oilers") at 2:35 of overtime. The Kings had trailed the Oilers 5–0 after the second period of game three of the Smythe Division Semi-final. This still remains the largest single game playoff comeback in NHL history.
  * May 5, 1986: [Doug Wickenheiser](/wiki/Doug_Wickenheiser "Doug Wickenheiser")'s overtime goal gives the St. Louis Blues a 6–5 win over the [Calgary Flames](/wiki/Calgary_Flames "Calgary Flames") in game six of the Campbell Conference Final. The goal, known as the "Monday Night Miracle", caps a 5–2 comeback and makes it more impressive that the three goals needed to tie the game were scored in the last ten minutes of the third period.
  * May 18, 1986: A [Brian Skrudland](/wiki/Brian_Skrudland "Brian Skrudland") goal ends the shortest overtime in NHL history at just nine seconds. The winning goal gives the Montreal Canadiens a 3–2 victory over the Calgary Flames in game two of the [1986 Stanley Cup Finals](/wiki/1986_Stanley_Cup_Finals "1986 Stanley Cup Finals").
  * April 18, 1987: "[Easter Epic](/wiki/Easter_Epic "Easter Epic")" – [Pat LaFontaine](/wiki/Pat_LaFontaine "Pat LaFontaine") of [New York Islanders](/wiki/New_York_Islanders "New York Islanders") scores a goal against [Washington Capitals](/wiki/Washington_Capitals "Washington Capitals") at 8:47 of quadruple overtime which ends the longest game seven in NHL playoff history. Islanders goaltender [Kelly Hrudey](/wiki/Kelly_Hrudey "Kelly Hrudey") makes a record 73 saves.
  * May 15, 1990: After hardly playing in overtime, [Petr Klima](/wiki/Petr_Kl%C3%ADma "Petr Klíma") came off the bench late in triple overtime and scored almost immediately to end the longest overtime in NHL Finals history, with 4:47 left. The goal gave the Edmonton Oilers a 3–2 victory over the Boston Bruins to open the [1990 Stanley Cup Finals](/wiki/1990_Stanley_Cup_Finals "1990 Stanley Cup Finals"), setting the stage for the Oilers' fifth cup in seven years.
  * April 24, 1993: In game four of the Adams division semi-final between the [Buffalo Sabres](/wiki/Buffalo_Sabres "Buffalo Sabres") and the Boston Bruins, Sabres forward [Brad May](/wiki/Brad_May "Brad May") scores in overtime to give Buffalo a 6–5 win and sweep the Bruins in the series, four games to none. Due to Buffalo commentator [Rick Jeanneret](/wiki/Rick_Jeanneret "Rick Jeanneret")'s colorful play call when May scored, this game has been referred to in Buffalo as "May Day".
  * April to June 1993: After losing in overtime of game one of the Adams division semi-final to the [Quebec Nordiques](/wiki/Quebec_Nordiques "Quebec Nordiques"), the Montreal Canadiens go on to win ten consecutive overtime games en route to winning the [Stanley Cup](/wiki/Stanley_Cup "Stanley Cup"). The Habs score another overtime winner the following year against the Boston Bruins, making it eleven consecutive playoff overtime wins.
  * May 14, 1993: In game seven of the Patrick Division Finals, [David Volek](/wiki/David_Volek "David Volek") who spent most of the season as a healthy scratch, scored the series winning goal to give the [New York Islanders](/wiki/New_York_Islanders "New York Islanders") a 4-3 victory ending the [Pittsburgh Penguins](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins "Pittsburgh Penguins") chances at a threepeat.
  * April 27, 1994: [Dominik Hašek](/wiki/Dominik_Ha%C5%A1ek "Dominik Hašek") of the Buffalo Sabres stops all 70 shots produced by the [New Jersey Devils](/wiki/New_Jersey_Devils "New Jersey Devils") as [Dave Hannan](/wiki/Dave_Hannan "Dave Hannan") scores the lone goal over a sprawling [Martin Brodeur](/wiki/Martin_Brodeur "Martin Brodeur") at 5:43 of quadruple overtime in game six of the Eastern Conference quarterfinal matchup.
  * April 30, 1994: [Pavel Bure](/wiki/Pavel_Bure "Pavel Bure") scores 2:20 into double overtime of the seventh game of the opening round of Vancouver's playoff series with Calgary. The win gives the [Vancouver Canucks](/wiki/Vancouver_Canucks "Vancouver Canucks") three consecutive overtime wins over the favored [Calgary Flames](/wiki/Calgary_Flames "Calgary Flames"), who squander a 3–1 series lead.
  * May 27, 1994: [Stéphane Matteau](/wiki/St%C3%A9phane_Matteau "Stéphane Matteau") scores the game-winning goal at 4:24 of double overtime with a wrap-around, beating [Martin Brodeur](/wiki/Martin_Brodeur "Martin Brodeur") and the New Jersey Devils in game seven, advancing the [New York Rangers](/wiki/New_York_Rangers "New York Rangers") to the Stanley Cup Finals (where they would ultimately win it for the first time since 1940). It is Matteau's second goal in double overtime periods of the series.
  * April 24, 1996: [Petr Nedved](/wiki/Petr_Nedv%C4%9Bd "Petr Nedvěd") scores with 44.6 seconds remaining in quadruple overtime to give the [Pittsburgh Penguins](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins "Pittsburgh Penguins") a 3–2 win over the [Washington Capitals](/wiki/Washington_Capitals "Washington Capitals") to tie their Eastern Conference quarter-final series at two games apiece.
  * June 6, 1996: [Uwe Krupp](/wiki/Uwe_Krupp "Uwe Krupp") became the 12th player in NHL history to end the Stanley Cup Finals in overtime, scoring a goal at 4:31 of triple overtime, giving the [Colorado Avalanche](/wiki/Colorado_Avalanche "Colorado Avalanche") a 1–0 win and a sweep of the [Florida Panthers](/wiki/Florida_Panthers "Florida Panthers").
  * June 19, 1999: [Brett Hull](/wiki/Brett_Hull "Brett Hull") scores with 5:09 left in triple overtime of game six to win the Stanley Cup for the [Dallas Stars](/wiki/Dallas_Stars "Dallas Stars") over the [Buffalo Sabres](/wiki/Buffalo_Sabres "Buffalo Sabres"). The goal is considered controversial by some fans due to disagreement on if the goal by Hull was legal or not. (see [1999 Stanley Cup Finals](/wiki/1999_Stanley_Cup_Finals "1999 Stanley Cup Finals")).
  * May 5, 2000: [Keith Primeau](/wiki/Keith_Primeau "Keith Primeau") of the [Philadelphia Flyers](/wiki/Philadelphia_Flyers "Philadelphia Flyers") put a shot over the left shoulder of [Pittsburgh Penguins](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins "Pittsburgh Penguins") goaltender [Ron Tugnutt](/wiki/Ron_Tugnutt "Ron Tugnutt") with 7:59 left in quintuple overtime, ending the longest game since 1936.
  * June 6, 2000: [Jason Arnott](/wiki/Jason_Arnott "Jason Arnott") scores on Dallas Stars' goalie [Ed Belfour](/wiki/Ed_Belfour "Ed Belfour") in double overtime of game six to give the New Jersey Devils their second Stanley Cup.
  * April 12, 2007: [Roberto Luongo](/wiki/Roberto_Luongo "Roberto Luongo"), goaltender for the Vancouver Canucks, wins his first career playoff game while making 72 saves, one shy of Kelly Hrudey's record. The game is the sixth longest ever, going into quadruple overtime. [Henrik Sedin](/wiki/Henrik_Sedin "Henrik Sedin") scores the winning goal in the Western Quarterfinals, beating the Dallas Stars 5–4 in game 1. The game is Vancouver's longest in history, and the Star's second longest, behind their five-overtime loss to Anaheim in 2003.
  * May 5, 2008: [Brenden Morrow](/wiki/Brenden_Morrow "Brenden Morrow") scores on [San Jose Sharks](/wiki/San_Jose_Sharks "San Jose Sharks") goalie [Evgeni Nabokov](/wiki/Evgeni_Nabokov "Evgeni Nabokov") at 9:03 of quadruple overtime in game six of the Western Conference Semi-final between the Sharks and Stars. The game sees an incredible goaltending duel as Nabokov makes 53 saves in the loss while [Marty Turco](/wiki/Marty_Turco "Marty Turco") of Dallas makes 61 saves for the win.
  * June 6, 2008: In game five of the [2008 Stanley Cup Finals](/wiki/2008_Stanley_Cup_Finals "2008 Stanley Cup Finals"), the [Pittsburgh Penguins](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins "Pittsburgh Penguins")' [Petr Sykora](/wiki/Petr_S%C3%BDkora "Petr Sýkora") told [Pierre Maguire](/wiki/Pierre_Maguire "Pierre Maguire") of [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC") that he would score the winning goal in overtime. At 9:57 of triple overtime, Sykora scored on Detroit Red Wings' goaltender [Chris Osgood](/wiki/Chris_Osgood "Chris Osgood") and sent the series back to Pittsburgh for game six.
  * June 6, 2010: [Patrick Kane](/wiki/Patrick_Kane "Patrick Kane") of the [Chicago Blackhawks](/wiki/Chicago_Blackhawks "Chicago Blackhawks") shoots a goal past [Philadelphia Flyers](/wiki/Philadelphia_Flyers "Philadelphia Flyers") goalie [Michael Leighton](/wiki/Michael_Leighton "Michael Leighton") 4:10 into overtime of game six of the Stanley Cup Finals to give the Blackhawks a 4–3 win over the Flyers for their first Stanley Cup Championship since 1961.
  * April 26, 2011: [Alexandre Burrows](/wiki/Alexandre_Burrows "Alexandre Burrows") of the [Vancouver Canucks](/wiki/Vancouver_Canucks "Vancouver Canucks") scored at 5:22 of overtime past [Corey Crawford](/wiki/Corey_Crawford "Corey Crawford") of the Chicago Blackhawks to win the series 4–3 and the game 2–1, sending the Canucks to the Western Conference Semifinals, avoiding squandering a 3–0 series lead and a 1–0 lead in game seven in the third period.
  * June 6, 2011: Another Burrows goal ends the second-shortest overtime in NHL history at just eleven seconds. The winning goal gives the Vancouver Canucks a 3–2 victory over the Boston Bruins in game two of the Stanley Cup Finals.
  * May 25, 2012: [Adam Henrique](/wiki/Adam_Henrique "Adam Henrique") of the New Jersey Devils scored at 1:03 into overtime past [Henrik Lundqvist](/wiki/Henrik_Lundqvist "Henrik Lundqvist") of the [New York Rangers](/wiki/New_York_Rangers "New York Rangers") in game six of the Eastern Conference Final to send the Devils to the Stanley Cup Finals for the first time since 2003.
  * May 13, 2013: [Patrice Bergeron](/wiki/Patrice_Bergeron "Patrice Bergeron") of the Boston Bruins scored at 6:05 of overtime past [James Reimer](/wiki/James_Reimer_\(ice_hockey\) "James Reimer \(ice hockey\)") of the Toronto Maple Leafs to win the series 4–3 and the game 5–4, to send the Bruins to the Conference Semifinals to face the Rangers. It also capped a historic comeback in a game seven, coming back from a three-goal deficit in the third period. With fifty–one seconds to go, they tied the game. The tying goal was also scored by Bergeron. The 2012–13 Boston Bruins became the first team in NHL history to do so in the [Stanley Cup playoffs](/wiki/Stanley_Cup_playoffs "Stanley Cup playoffs").
  * June 6, 2013: [Andrew Shaw](/wiki/Andrew_Shaw_\(ice_hockey\) "Andrew Shaw \(ice hockey\)") scored with 7:52 left in triple overtime as the Chicago Blackhawks beat the [Boston Bruins](/wiki/Boston_Bruins "Boston Bruins") 4-3 to open the Stanley Cup Finals, ending the fifth-longest game in Stanley Cup Finals history.
  * June 13, 2014: [Alec Martinez](/wiki/Alec_Martinez "Alec Martinez") scored with 5:17 left in double overtime in game five of the [2014 Stanley Cup Finals](/wiki/2014_Stanley_Cup_Finals "2014 Stanley Cup Finals"), becoming the 16th player to win the Stanley Cup with an overtime goal as the [Los Angeles Kings](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Kings "Los Angeles Kings") beat the Rangers 3–2, clinching the title 4–1. He became the first player to score two series-clinching playoff overtime goals in the same season since [Martin Gelinas](/wiki/Martin_Gelinas "Martin Gelinas") in 2004; on June 1, he scored 5:47 into overtime to defeat the Chicago Blackhawks 5–4 in game seven of the Western Conference Finals.
  * May 13, 2015: [Derek Stepan](/wiki/Derek_Stepan "Derek Stepan") scored with 8:36 left in the first overtime in game seven in the Eastern Conference Second Round against the [Washington Capitals](/wiki/Washington_Capitals "Washington Capitals") to send the [New York Rangers](/wiki/New_York_Rangers "New York Rangers") to the Eastern Conference Finals. The Capitals also had a 3–1 series lead before losing the final three games and ultimately losing the series.
  * May 19, 2015: [Marcus Kruger](/wiki/Marcus_Kr%C3%BCger "Marcus Krüger") scored with 3:48 left in the third overtime in game two of the Western Conference Finals, as the Chicago Blackhawks beat the [Anaheim Ducks](/wiki/Anaheim_Ducks "Anaheim Ducks"), 3–2, tying the series at 1–1. This was Anaheim's first playoff loss at home that season and Chicago's longest overtime game to date. Chicago goalie [Corey Crawford](/wiki/Corey_Crawford "Corey Crawford") made 60 saves while defenceman [Duncan Keith](/wiki/Duncan_Keith "Duncan Keith") played seconds shy of 50 minutes on ice. Earlier in the second overtime period, Andrew Shaw used his head to direct the puck into the net, but the goal did not count.
  * April 24, 2016: [John Tavares](/wiki/John_Tavares_\(ice_hockey\) "John Tavares \(ice hockey\)") scored the series-winner with 9:19 left in double overtime in game six of the Eastern Conference First Round as the New York Islanders won a playoff series for the first time since 1993, beating the Florida Panthers 2–1, to win the series 4–2. He beat Roberto Luongo off a rebound of his own shot with a wraparound. It ended the longest home game in Islanders' history. Tavares also scored with 53.2 seconds left in regulation to force overtime. Three of those games in this series have gone to overtime, this and game five needed two.
  * May 6, 2016: [Mike Fisher](/wiki/Mike_Fisher_\(ice_hockey\) "Mike Fisher \(ice hockey\)") scored with 8:48 left in triple overtime in game four of the Western Conference Second Round as the [Nashville Predators](/wiki/Nashville_Predators "Nashville Predators") beat the San Jose Sharks, 4–3, to tie the series at two games all. His goal ended the longest playoff game in Predators' history. [Joe Pavelski](/wiki/Joe_Pavelski "Joe Pavelski") could have won it at 7:34 of overtime, but officials waved it off as he crashed into [Pekka Rinne](/wiki/Pekka_Rinne "Pekka Rinne"), pinning him down before the puck crossed the goal line.
  * May 25, 2017: [Chris Kunitz](/wiki/Chris_Kunitz "Chris Kunitz") scored at 5:09 of double overtime as the Pittsburgh Penguins beat the Ottawa Senators to advance to play the Nashville Predators in the Stanley Cup Finals in winning game seven of the Eastern Conference Finals, 3-2. [Sidney Crosby](/wiki/Sidney_Crosby "Sidney Crosby") sent a soft backhand pass to Kunitz, whose knuckling shot beat [Craig Anderson](/wiki/Craig_Anderson_\(ice_hockey\) "Craig Anderson \(ice hockey\)") from the right faceoff circle.
  * April 13, 2018: The [Vegas Golden Knights](/wiki/Vegas_Golden_Knights "Vegas Golden Knights") won their first-ever playoff overtime game when [Erik Haula](/wiki/Erik_Haula "Erik Haula") scored with 4:37 left in double overtime to beat the Los Angeles Kings 2–1 to take a 2–0 lead in the Western Conference First Round. Haula made it to the right wing after a [James Neal](/wiki/James_Neal_\(ice_hockey\) "James Neal \(ice hockey\)") pass, faked his shot, then beat [Jonathan Quick](/wiki/Jonathan_Quick "Jonathan Quick") with a forehand.
  * May 7, 2018: [Evgeny Kuznetsov](/wiki/Evgeny_Kuznetsov "Evgeny Kuznetsov") scored at 5:27 of overtime as the Washington Capitals eliminated the two-time defending champion Pittsburgh Penguins in game six of the Eastern Conference Second Round to advance to the Conference Finals for the first time in 20 years. [Alexander Ovechkin](/wiki/Alexander_Ovechkin "Alexander Ovechkin") passed the puck back to Kuznetsov, who tapped it away from Sidney Crosby on a turnover before beating [Matt Murray](/wiki/Matt_Murray_\(ice_hockey\) "Matt Murray \(ice hockey\)") between the pads.

###
DEL[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: DEL")]

March 22, 2008: [Philip Gogulla](/wiki/Philip_Gogulla "Philip Gogulla") of the
[Cologne Sharks](/wiki/K%C3%B6lner_Haie "Kölner Haie") ends the longest German
hockey game ever and the third longest worldwide, scoring the ninth-overall
goal in a 5:4 victory over the [Mannheim Eagles](/wiki/Adler_Mannheim "Adler
Mannheim"). The goal comes 8:16 into the sixth overtime period for a total of
108:16 of overtime. It is the third quarter-final game (best of seven) in the
[Kölnarena](/wiki/K%C3%B6lnarena "Kölnarena") in Cologne in front of an
audience of 17,000. The game had begun at 5:30 pm and ends at 12:15 am.

### Norwegian

March 12, 2017: [Joakim Jensen](/wiki/Joakim_Jensen "Joakim Jensen") of the
[Storhamar Ishockey](/wiki/Storhamar_Ishockey "Storhamar Ishockey") ends the
longest hockey game in history, scoring with 2:46 left in octuple overtime for
a total of 157:14 of overtime, and 217:14 of hockey played. It was Game 5 of
the quarter-finals of the [2016–17 GET-ligaen
playoffs](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_GET-ligaen_season#Playoffs "2016–17 GET-ligaen
season") against the [Sparta Warriors](/wiki/Sparta_Warriors "Sparta
Warriors") in the [CC Amfi](/wiki/CC_Amfi "CC Amfi"). About 1,000 out of the
5,500 people that attended the game watched the entire game. The game started
at 18:00 and ended at 2:32 the next morning.[22]

#### Canadian Interuniversity Sport –
men[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Canadian Interuniversity Sport – men")]

The [University of New Brunswick](/wiki/University_of_New_Brunswick
"University of New Brunswick") [Varsity
Reds](/wiki/University_of_New_Brunswick "University of New Brunswick") needed
61:53 of overtime (four extra periods) to defeat the [Acadia
University](/wiki/Acadia_University "Acadia University")
[Axemen](/wiki/Acadia_Axemen "Acadia Axemen") 3–2 on February 27, 2011 in game
two of a best-of-five AUS semi-final series at [Fredericton, New
Brunswick](/wiki/Fredericton,_New_Brunswick "Fredericton, New Brunswick").
Nick MacNeil scored the game-winner at 11:53 of the seventh period overall.

[York University](/wiki/York_University "York University")
[Lions](/wiki/York_Lions "York Lions") and [Lakehead
University](/wiki/Lakehead_University "Lakehead University")
[Thunderwolves](/wiki/Lakehead_Thunderwolves "Lakehead Thunderwolves") went to
a fourth overtime period (50:13 minutes of overtime) on February 14, 2007 in
[Thunder Bay, Ontario](/wiki/Thunder_Bay,_Ontario "Thunder Bay, Ontario"), to
decide a winner in OUA men's playoff hockey action. Lakehead won the game at
the 13-second mark of the fourth overtime period.

#### Canadian Interuniversity Sport –
women[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Canadian Interuniversity Sport – women")]

Morgan McHaffie scored at 17:14 of the sixth overtime period to lead the
[Queen's Golden Gaels](/wiki/Queen%27s_Golden_Gaels "Queen's Golden Gaels") to
a 2–1 win over the host [Guelph Gryphons](/wiki/Guelph_Gryphons "Guelph
Gryphons") in the first game of the best-of-three OUA women's hockey final,
March 2, 2011. The game, which lasted 167 minutes and 14 seconds, including
107:14 of extra time, is the longest on record in CIS or NCAA hockey – women's
or men's. Winning goaltender Mel Dodd-Moher made 66 saves, while Danielle
Skoufranis made 44 saves in a losing cause. It is the longest game ever played
sanctioned by [Hockey Canada](/wiki/Hockey_Canada "Hockey Canada").

#### International Hockey
League[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: International Hockey League")]

On May 12, 2008, one of the longest games in IHL history, if not the longest,
took place in [Fort Wayne, Indiana](/wiki/Fort_Wayne,_Indiana "Fort Wayne,
Indiana"). It was the seventh game of the [Turner Cup](/wiki/Turner_Cup
"Turner Cup") Final between the hometown [Fort Wayne
Komets](/wiki/Fort_Wayne_Komets "Fort Wayne Komets") and [Port Huron
Icehawks](/wiki/Port_Huron_Icehawks "Port Huron Icehawks"). The game was tied
2–2 through regulation. The first two extra periods solved nothing, but 23
seconds into the third overtime period, at some point after midnight ET,
Justin Hodgman scored the winning goal to give the Komets their fifth Turner
Cup title. It was the club's first since 1993, and their sixth overall, with
their last championship being the [Colonial Cup](/wiki/Colonial_Cup_\(hockey\)
"Colonial Cup \(hockey\)") in 2003. The Komets would win again the following
year with an easy game five victory at home, which was the first time in
franchise history they won back-to-back championships. They would follow up
with a third consecutive Turner Cup in 2010, again clinching on home ice,
securing a dynasty.

####
VHL[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: VHL")]

On April 25, 2018, in game 5 of the 2018 [VHL](/wiki/Supreme_Hockey_League
"Supreme Hockey League") finals, [SKA-Neva](/wiki/SKA-Neva "SKA-Neva")
defeated [HC Dinamo Saint Petersburg](/wiki/HC_Dinamo_Saint_Petersburg "HC
Dinamo Saint Petersburg") 4-3 in a game that needed 103:36 of overtime to be
settled. Svyatoslav Grebinshchikov scored the game-winning goal 3:36 of
sextuple overtime.[23]

####
NCAA[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: NCAA")]

The longest game in [NCAA](/wiki/NCAA "NCAA") hockey history was played on
March 6–7, 2015. [UMass](/wiki/University_of_Massachusetts_Amherst "University
of Massachusetts Amherst") beat [Notre Dame](/wiki/Notre_Dame_University
"Notre Dame University"), 4–3, in the [Hockey East](/wiki/Hockey_East "Hockey
East") first-round playoff game after 91:42 of overtime. Shane Walsh scored
the winning goal for UMass.[24][25]

Overall game length  
(min:sec) | Overtime length | Number of overtimes | Winning team | Score | Losing team | Where it occurred | Date  
---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---

150:22 | 90:22 | 5 | [Quinnipiac University](/wiki/Quinnipiac_University "Quinnipiac University") | 3–2 | [Union College](/wiki/Union_College "Union College") | ECACH Quarter-Finals (Game 1, Best of 3) | March 12, 2010

129:30 | 69:30 | 4 | [Colorado College](/wiki/Colorado_College "Colorado College") | 1–0 | [Wisconsin Badgers](/wiki/Wisconsin_Badgers "Wisconsin Badgers") | WCHA First Round (Game 2, Best of 3) | March 3, 1997

121:05 | 61:05 | 4 | [Colgate University](/wiki/Colgate_University "Colgate University") | 4–3 | [Dartmouth College](/wiki/Dartmouth_College "Dartmouth College") | ECAC Quarterfinal (Game 1, Best of 3) | March 14, 2003  
  
The longest game in NCAA hockey history was played at [Notre
Dame](/wiki/University_of_Notre_Dame "University of Notre Dame") in [South
Bend, Indiana](/wiki/South_Bend,_Indiana "South Bend, Indiana") on March 6,
2015. [UMass](/wiki/University_of_Massachusetts_Amherst "University of
Massachusetts Amherst") beat [Notre Dame](/wiki/University_of_Notre_Dame
"University of Notre Dame"), 4–3, in the [Hockey East](/wiki/Hockey_East
"Hockey East") first round with 8:18 left in quintuple overtime. Shane Walsh
scored the winning goal just after 1:00 am local time. The previous longest
was played on March 12, 2010. [Quinnipiac
University](/wiki/Quinnipiac_University "Quinnipiac University") beat [Union
College](/wiki/Union_College "Union College"), 3–2, in the
[ECAC](/wiki/Eastern_College_Athletic_Conference "Eastern College Athletic
Conference") Quarterfinals, as Greg Holt scored with 9:38 left in quintuple
overtime. The 3rd longest game in NCAA hockey history was played on March 5,
2006. [Yale University](/wiki/Yale_University "Yale University") beat Union
College, 3–2, in the [ECAC](/wiki/Eastern_College_Athletic_Conference "Eastern
College Athletic Conference") Hockey League first-round playoff game after
81:35 of overtime. [David Meckler](/wiki/David_Meckler "David Meckler") scored
the winning goal with Yale shorthanded.[26]

The longest game in [NCAA Division III](/wiki/NCAA_Division_III "NCAA Division
III") hockey history, and the fourth longest in NCAA history overall, began at
7:05 pm on February 27, 2010 and ended at 12:35 am of the following day.
[Gustavus Adolphus College](/wiki/Gustavus_Adolphus_College "Gustavus Adolphus
College") beat [Augsburg College](/wiki/Augsburg_College "Augsburg College"),
6–5, to advance to the
[MIAC](/wiki/Minnesota_Intercollegiate_Athletic_Conference "Minnesota
Intercollegiate Athletic Conference") championship game after 78:38 of
overtime. Eric Bigham scored the winning goal.[27]

A 2000 NCAA regional final in men's ice hockey between St. Lawrence University
and Boston University ended with 63:53 of overtime. Manitoba native and minor
hockey buddy of Craig McAulay, Robin Carruthers scored the gwg after four
periods of overtime play

A March 30, 1991 game between [Northern Michigan
University](/wiki/Northern_Michigan_University "Northern Michigan University")
and [Boston University](/wiki/Boston_University "Boston University") ended
with Northern Michigan earning an 8–7 victory over Boston University. Unlikely
hero Darryl Plandowski scores in the third overtime period and fifth hour of
play to give the Wildcats the title.

A March 8, 1997 game between [Colorado College](/wiki/Colorado_College
"Colorado College") and the [University of
Wisconsin–Madison](/wiki/University_of_Wisconsin%E2%80%93Madison "University
of Wisconsin–Madison") ended with Colorado College winning, 1–0, after 69:30.

A March 14, 2003 ECAC Quarterfinal game between [Colgate
University](/wiki/Colgate_University "Colgate University") and Dartmouth
ended, 4–3 for Colgate, after 61:05 in overtime.

On March 26, 2006, the Wisconsin Badgers beat the [Cornell Big
Red](/wiki/Cornell_Big_Red "Cornell Big Red") 1–0 at 11:13 into the third
overtime at the Midwest Regional Final in the [NCAA
Tournament](/wiki/NCAA_Men%27s_Ice_Hockey_Championship "NCAA Men's Ice Hockey
Championship") at the [Resch Center](/wiki/Resch_Center "Resch Center") in
[Green Bay](/wiki/Green_Bay,_Wisconsin "Green Bay, Wisconsin"). It was the
second-longest NCAA Tournament game in its history and the longest 1–0 game in
tournament history. It is currently the ninth-longest game all-time in NCAA
Division I history.

An March 11, 2007 game between [St. Cloud State
University](/wiki/St._Cloud_State_University "St. Cloud State University") and
[University of Minnesota Duluth](/wiki/University_of_Minnesota_Duluth
"University of Minnesota Duluth") during the first round of the
[WCHA](/wiki/Western_Collegiate_Hockey_Association "Western Collegiate Hockey
Association") playoffs ended with SCSU winning, 3–2, after 51:33 of overtime.
It is the eighth-longest NCAA Division I game in history.

In the first round of the 2008
[WCHA](/wiki/Western_Collegiate_Hockey_Association "Western Collegiate Hockey
Association") hockey tournament featuring the fourth-seeded [Minnesota State
University, Mankato](/wiki/Minnesota_State_University,_Mankato "Minnesota
State University, Mankato") Mavericks hosting the seventh-seeded [University
of Minnesota](/wiki/University_of_Minnesota "University of Minnesota") Golden
Gophers, the Friday and Sunday games both went into double overtime, and the
Saturday night game went into one overtime. The Gophers prevailed two games to
one in the series, winning Saturday and Sunday.

On March 3, 2012, in the first round of the 2012 [ECAC
Hockey](/wiki/ECAC_Hockey "ECAC Hockey") hockey tournament featuring the
seventh-seeded [Clarkson Golden Knights men's ice
hockey](/wiki/Clarkson_Golden_Knights_men%27s_ice_hockey "Clarkson Golden
Knights men's ice hockey") team hosting the tenth-seeded [RPI Engineers men's
ice hockey](/wiki/RPI_Engineers_men%27s_ice_hockey "RPI Engineers men's ice
hockey") team, Clarkson beat RPI 4–3 at 13:48 in the third overtime period,
after 113:48 of play. It is currently the seventh-longest game all-time in
NCAA Division I history.

#### NCAA
Women[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: NCAA Women")]

On March 10, 1996, New Hampshire defeated Providence, 3–2, in an ECAC Women's
Championship game after 85:35 of overtime. (This is not an NCAA record, as the
NCAA did not officially recognize women's hockey until the 2001 season;
however, it stands as the longest women's college hockey game)[28]

On March 10, 2007, Wisconsin defeated Harvard, 1–0, in an NCAA Women's
Quarterfinal game after 67:09 of overtime at the Kohl Center in Madison WI.
Wisconsin went on to win the national championship.

On March 10, 2012, Cornell University defeated Boston University, 8–7, in an
NCAA Women's Quarterfinal game after 59:50 of overtime at Lynah Rink in
Ithaca, New York, surpassing the men's game from the previous night as the
longest hockey game to be played at the rink.[29]

On March 21, 2010, Minnesota-Duluth defeated Cornell 3–2 in the NCAA
championship game, after 59:26 of overtime (119:26 total game time), the
longest men's or women's hockey championship game in NCAA history.[30]

#### Canadian Hockey
League[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Canadian Hockey League")]

  * The longest game in Memorial Cup history was played on May 23, 2014 in [London, Ontario](/wiki/London,_Ontario "London, Ontario"), where in the semi-final game, Curtis Lazar scored at 2:42 of triple overtime as the [Edmonton Oil Kings](/wiki/Edmonton_Oil_Kings "Edmonton Oil Kings") beat the [Val-d'Or Foreurs](/wiki/Val-d%27Or_Foreurs "Val-d'Or Foreurs") 4–3 to advance to the championship game. The entire overtime lasted 42:42, the overall game time played was 102:42.
  * The longest game in WHL & CHL history was played on April 2, 2017 in [Victoria, BC](/wiki/Victoria,_BC "Victoria, BC"), in Game 6 of Round 1 between the [Everett Silvertips](/wiki/Everett_Silvertips "Everett Silvertips") and [Victoria Royals](/wiki/Victoria_Royals "Victoria Royals"). Cal Babych scored with 8:24 left in quintuple overtime to beat the Royals 3-2 to win the series 4-2. The total game time played was 151:36.
  * The longest game in QMJHL history was played on April 3, 2016 in [Boisbriand](/wiki/Boisbriand "Boisbriand"), [Quebec](/wiki/Quebec "Quebec"), where in a first-round game, Philippe Sanche scored with 7:34 left in triple overtime as the [Blainville-Boisbriand Armada](/wiki/Blainville-Boisbriand_Armada "Blainville-Boisbriand Armada") beat the [Val-d'Or Foreurs](/wiki/Val-d%27Or_Foreurs "Val-d'Or Foreurs") 3-2 to advance to the quarterfinals. The entire overtime lasted 52:26, the overall game time played was 112:26.

#### 2007 RBC Cup – Canadian Jr A
Championship[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: 2007 RBC Cup – Canadian Jr A Championship")]

The semi-final game for the 2007 RBC Cup, saw the host Prince George Spruce
Kings taking on the Camrose Kodiaks. The game ended up being the longest game
in Royal Bank Cup history at 146 minutes and 1 second. The Spruce Kings broke
a 2–2 tie just over six minutes into the fifth overtime period to win 3–2 and
clinch a berth in the RBC Cup Final against the Aurora Tigers. Jason Yuel of
the Spruce Kings scored the winner while goaltender Jordan White stopped 91 of
93 shots for the victory.

####
OPJHL[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: OPJHL")]

On February 10, 2007, the [Toronto Jr. Canadiens](/wiki/Toronto_Jr._Canadiens
"Toronto Jr. Canadiens") defeated the [Pickering
Panthers](/wiki/Pickering_Panthers "Pickering Panthers"), 4–3, to take a 2–0
series lead in the first round of the
[OPJHL](/wiki/Ontario_Provincial_Junior_A_Hockey_League "Ontario Provincial
Junior A Hockey League") playoffs, after 104:32 of overtime. It is the second
longest game ever played sanctioned by [Hockey Canada](/wiki/Hockey_Canada
"Hockey Canada").

####
GHJHL[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: GHJHL")]

February 1999, the St. Catharines Falcons defeated the Port Colborne Sailors
7–6 to take a 2–1 series lead in the semi-finals of the Golden Horseshoe Jr. B
Hockey League Playoffs. Peter Lacey scored 11 minutes into the fifth overtime
period, ending the game at 2:18 am. The game started at 7:30 pm. It is the
longest junior hockey game sanctioned by Hockey Canada

#### High
school[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: High school")]

Marquette vs Orchard Lake St Marys went eight overtimes during the
[Michigan](/wiki/Michigan_High_School_Athletic_Association "Michigan High
School Athletic Association") State Ice Hockey Division 1 Championship game
before Tournament officials stopped the game in consideration of the health
and welfare of the players on March 8, 2008. The 1–1 tie resulted in the two
teams being declared co-champions. The game lasted 109 minutes.[31] Ryan
Morley Stockton of St. Mary's had a MHSAA-record 58 saves.[32]

The longest game in high school history was in a 1996 [FCIAC](/wiki/FCIAC
"FCIAC") quarterfinal matchup in [Darien,
Connecticut](/wiki/Darien,_Connecticut "Darien, Connecticut") between
archrivals [Wilton](/wiki/Wilton_High_School "Wilton High School") and
[Ridgefield](/wiki/Ridgefield_High_School_\(Connecticut\) "Ridgefield High
School \(Connecticut\)") that went to a tenth eight-minute overtime period
after 45 minutes of regulation (125:00 of hockey). Chris Ludwig of Wilton
scored the game-winner while being hauled down in front of the Ridgefield net
in the tenth overtime period.

The previous record belonged to the [Aurora High
School](/wiki/Aurora_High_School_\(Aurora,_Ohio\) "Aurora High School
\(Aurora, Ohio\)")–[Solon High School](/wiki/Solon_High_School "Solon High
School") game in which Aurora won in the eighth overtime period of the
[Ohio](/wiki/Ohio_High_School_Athletic_Association "Ohio High School Athletic
Association") state playoffs.[33] The winning goal was scored with 3:52 left
in the 8th overtime (105th minute), setting an American record.[34]

Since 2015, all state tournaments allow up to 5 overtime periods (4-on-4 after
first overtime), after which best-of-3-round shootouts and extra rounds if
needed are conducted, to eliminate co-champions.
